Spitzer contends Canary entered into quid pro quo agreement with Bank of America's fund business that allowed Canary to buy and sell fund shares after market closed and then trade them next day for substantial profit; state and federal securities law prohibit investors to buy or sell mutual fund shares--at that day's price--after market has closed and then profit by trading them next day; Bank of America's funds allegedly received hundreds of millions in investments from Stern as well as commissions; Kozlowski is on trial with former chief financial officer Mark H Swartz; photo (M)")('2003093', 'Correction of Sept 29 report on plans to publish Killed, anthology of magazine article that were originally rejected, regarding one contributor cited')('2003093', 'University of Bristol researchers, writing in BMJ, British medical journal, find that chronic disease plays greater role in falls for older adults than any medications they may be taking; 17 percent of women who are between 60 and 79 report having fallen at least once in past 12 months and three-quarters of those women suffer from chronic diseases; cartoon (S)')('2003093', 'Jane E Brody Personal Health column explains how addiction causes biological changes within human brain that effect ability to recover and give up drug; contends that addiction is brain disease that causes chronic mental illness and requires treatment strategies that go beyond cessation of substance abuse; New England Journal of Medicine report, by Barcelona (Spain) Drs Jordi Cami and Magi Farre, describes adaptive changes within central nervous system that support concept that addiction itself is not behavioral, even though many people begin to use drugs for social or behavioral reasons; holds certain personality traits and mental disorders can increase likelihood of becoming addict; drawing (M)')('2003093', "South Korean President Roh Moo Hyun discontinues his membership in Millennium Democratic Party shortly after 37 lawmakers leave party to form new People's Participatory United New Party (S)")('2003093', 'New York Yankees prepare for Game 1 of playoff series against Minnesota Twins; photos (M)')('2003093', 'Q & A column on brain infection called fungal cerebral mucormycosis; drawing (S)')('2003093', 'Dr Don J Melnick, Columbia University Center for Environmental Research and Conservation director, and Dr Prithiviraj Fernando, scientist at center, publish report in Public Library of Science, Biology, that overturns theory that Borneo elephants are domesticated descendants of Asian elephants; DNA testing finds that genetic differences between Borneo and Asian elephants could not have occurred in short time since Indian elephants were allegedly presented to Sultan of Sulu by East India Trading Company; report theorizes that elephants may have colonized Borneo during Pleistocene when land bridges were present; data, however, does suggest elephants may have been isolated even before that time; researchers call for designation of new subspecies, but until more study is complete, have termed Borneo elephant, numbering between 1,000 to 2,500, as evolutionary significant unit; urge increased efforts at preservation; map; photo (M)')('2003093', "Air France's board approves proposed stock swap with KLM shareholders; no deal has been reached; labor union representatives on Air France's board oppose proposal (M)")('2003093', 'International team of researchers, led by Dr Erik Trinkaus, Washington University (St Louis) paleontologist, announces dating of jawbone found in cave in Carpathian Mountains in journal Proceedings of National Academy of Sciences; radiocarbon analysis dates jaw, complete with set of molars, at 34,000 to 36,000 years, making it earliest fossil evidence found of modern humans in Europe; researchers hold that unusually large molar size suggests interbreeding between modern humans and Neanderthals; photo (M)')('2003093', "European Commission approves rules that would require all publicly traded companies in European Union to adopt common accounting standards by 2005, though it leaves out regulations that are being revised after opposition from banks; Frits Bolkestein, union's single market commissioner, comments; photo (S)")
